content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: 4 feet right of Dog Day

content.description:
Step across the dark pit into the good crack(scary), and follow the crack. 

  This route can be started from within the pit, in fact this looks like the truer line with about 20 feet of added climbing.
content.protection:
Hand and fist sized cams. 

  Finger sized cams if starting from within the cave.
content.location: Near the apex of the piled boulders with pits behind them.

content.description: Broken start into the clean arete.  Rated 5.10b in Jackson's guide, I never found any real difficulties (albeit on toprope).  Has been led w/ cams in pockets.
content.location: Arete between Endless Summer & Pete's Down Climb.

content.description: This TR route is pumpy and unrelenting.The face has remnants of bolts, but no hangers. Many small edges, pockets, and cool sequences will get you to the top of the Right on Raton anchor.
content.location: On the face to the left of Right on Raton. Follow the bolt line to the top.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: Next dihedral to the right of the A-Frame

content.description: Steep face leading to shallow dihedral.  Start is tough and sequential, slowly eases toward the anchor.
content.location: About 15' right of Dog Day (Yo Mamma is in between).  Just left of obvious splitter crack of Jam Your Blues away.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: [Needs location]

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: Climbs the crack about 20 feet right of the start of March Madness with it's overhang half way up

content.description: Fallow the first half of Motengator than about half way up deviate left to a crack follow to the top.
content.location: Variation of Motengator

content.description: This is a smooth looking off-width crack that heads up to a small roof, go left at the roof and follow the smaller crack to the lip.I climbed Soma Hiliday the other day and it is NOT the off width crack to the right. Soma Holiday starts as a very thin crack with tricky moves at the bottom that is left of the off-width. Dennis Jackson’s guide shows this. It is not the off-width. The climb gets considerably easier after the first tricky moves. Definitely not the 10b/c it is given by Jackson. The off-width to the left is unnamed as are so many other climbs at Sugarite.
content.protection: bring big cams, #6 BDs for the first 30', after that it is hand sized cams to micros to the top
content.location: Start in the off-width crack with the roof near the top. further right than the great roof.

content.description: Worth climbing. A curving hand crack to the right of a perched boulder at the base of the cliff.
content.protection:
Hands and smaller cams will do the trick. 

  For anchor placement there is a boulder about 10' from the lip, that takes small cams in it's pockets and 1 hands sized cam for a single larger pocket. 3 peace anchor possible if you are creative.
content.location: This route is pretty far down the cliff, keep walking right until you see the striking curving crack.

content.description: Beautiful arete. Vertical face climbing on big pockets.  Being tall helps (but is not required).  4 bolts to anchor at top.
content.location: Next route right of Salt Mother.

content.description: Nice splitter with a crux down low (past the broken rock).  Continuous 5.7 after the low crux.
content.location: Next route right of Pete's Down Climb (an offwidth).  Broken rock to a nice thin hands crack.

content.description: S&M Crack is one of three routes at Sugarite dubbed as "megaclassics" by Dennis Jackson in his "Rock Climbing New Mexico" book.  At 75 feet in length it is also the longest route at Sugarite.    Start off some blocks at the base following some broken flakes and finger crack from protection up to a large roof/bulge.  Pull up and around the roof via some committing laybacking to the hand crack above.     If you're pumped like I was, a large ledge just off to the left about half way up the route offers a very good rest before you fire up the upper half.    Follow the overhanging hand crack with small edges for feet on the face for another 25 feet to the top.  Watch for some loose rocks on top.
content.protection: BD cams... Doubles of .3, .75, 1, 2. Singles of .4, .5, 3.  Two-bolt anchor at the top just to the left of this crack serves as a rappel anchor too.
content.location: Far right side of the wall.  The long crack is obvious.

content.description:
Up the hand crack starting from the 5' boulder directly behind Zoid's Tower. A couple of the lower moves are thought-provoking, but there's nothing too strenuous and the protection is abundant.  

  As with most of the other moderates at Sugarite, the stances are great and the going gets easier as you go higher. An excellent intro to leading 5.8 trad.
content.protection: Standard rack, doubling up on hand-sized pieces (BD 1,2).
content.location: RoR is mid-wall, just behind Zoid's Tower. There are a couple of anchors and a chain at the top.

content.description: This climb starts at the bottom of the cave below Wounded Knee. Climb up amazing finger locks and interesting mantles for 25 feet into the start of Wounded Knee. Continue up Wounded Knee to the top.
content.protection: first half of the climb is finger lock sizes, the second half is fist sized cams.
content.location: In the cave below Wounded Knee

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: 30 feet right of Jam Your Blues Away.

content.description: "Primo" says Dennis Jackson. Led first with pre-placed protection.    [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]

A nice hand to 'rather-wide' crack in a right-facing dihedral to the left of most of the routes listed here.  You can climb the whole thing using ledges and pockets instead of the crack, but bring bigger gear.
content.protection:
Cams from #3 to #5.  We found a perfect placement for the smallest big bro in this crack as well!   

  Oh yeah, there's a pair of bolts on top, but nothing to rap off with aside from the hangers.  This is fine for top-roping, but you might want to rap off of a different anchor to save your rope a bit of wear.

content.description: Area classic.    [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.protection: Go left at the top to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: [Needs location information]

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.protection: Standard small peices, no anchors at top
content.location: Start is on aret right of striking offwidth

climbs.name: The Optimator
climbs.fa: Pete Takeda with pre-placed pro in 1999

content.description: An improbable looking climb first lead by Pete Takeda in 1999 with pre-placed protection. Dennis Jackson's guidebook says there has not been a recorded second ascent.    [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.protection: Small cams and nuts, bring extra confidence.
content.location: Starts on a black looking wall about 50 feet right of The Arrowhead, up high the route becomes more featured.

content.description: One of the great cracks just to the right of the "great roof."  Steeper, trickier, and more sustained than you might expect.
content.protection: Standard light rack - cams to fist sized

content.description: Fun route just to the left of Crack from Hell.  Delicate techy climbing, more like 5.9+ Eldo type climbing.  Fragile rock but fun moves.
content.protection: Mainly small nuts, double aliens and a few mid size cams.   Red camalot is nice at top for directional to then belay off the chains on Crack From Hell
content.location: Starts pretty high up where you have to step across the chasm to reach the flake at the base.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: Right of the piled boulders it has the obvious small overhang half way up.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: Thin crack right of roofed crack climb Soma Holiday

content.description: Straight up the hand crack.
content.location: left-center area of cliff with beautiful orange rock.

content.description:
Near the left side of the cliff at Sugarite is a gigantic roof.  The crack that passes the left side of the roof is the classic Great Roof Left.  Less classic but still fun is the crack that passes the right side.  Start up a huge flake that goes easy but unprotected (unless you have a #6 camalot or some big bros) to some dodgy-looking but solid blocks just below the roof.  Get some good pro in at the edge of the roof and pull some strenuous jamming and laybacking up around the roof to easier and fun hand jamming to the top. Heavy amounts of lichen on the left side of the crack keep the foot placements interesting to the top.  

  It's a fun route but not very consistent. Easy climbing to the roof, a tough move around the roof and then easier climbing above.  Still worth doing, though.  

  FA info would be greatly appreciated. Also, suggested rating info would be nice too. The 5.10a rating is just our guess since we haven't seen anything published about this route. The move around the roof is definitely more challenging than any single move on Great Roof Left but overall the route is much less sustained.
content.protection: BD cams... .5, .75, 2x #2, 2x #3 and some gear for the anchor (good anchor gear is a #4 and a #3.)
content.location: Near the far left side of the wall.

content.description: Start under big roof.  Suprise! Climb up and out the left side.  The roof move is much easier than it looks from the ground.
content.location: Next route right of Crack head.  Find the big roof.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: Just a few feet right of Right On Raton

content.description: A Pete Takeda test-piece. Start in the ditch like pit, up some easy moves and over a very small roof to a TINY left leaning RP crack. This route looks insane, not to mention the tiny horrible pro. Supposedly unrepeated.
content.location: 1st route in the pit, you will know the pit when you see it.

content.description: Recognizable by the obvious bolt-protected traverse near the bottom, then up a thin crack in a dihedral.  Lots of lichen, but fun.    No anchors but you can use the bolts on the neighboring "Up Your Arete"
content.protection: Thin cams & nuts, maybe some cams in pockets.
content.location: Near the left end of the climbable wall.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: about 40 feet right of Bat Dog and about 50 feet left of S&M Crack in a good dihedral.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: Just left of March Madness with it's small roof half way up.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: Just a few feet right of Double D Left

content.description:
Dennis Jackson's jackson's guide is a little convoluted concerning this route. He reports this is an excellent route. 

  [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: 20 feet right of Type O

content.description: Next route right of Crazy Cams.  Mostly pockets and thin crack.
content.location: Near left-middle section of the cliff.

content.description: Continuous with tough to place pro.  Fun pockets and thin crack
content.location: About 30-40 yards right of the left edge of the cliff.  There is a gaping chimney about 20 feet to its left.  Shallow dihedral with discontinuous crack.

content.description: Crack in corner.  Hands & thin hands mostly, lots of face holds.  Bolted anchor.
content.location: Next route right of Sangre Verde.  Crack in dihedral.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.protection: Standard with hands sized cams, bring a few extra BD #3-4's for the anchor.
content.location: Just a few feet right of Miami Vice

content.description: This crack is awesome. It is a very thin long crack on the left side of a whitish flake.
content.location: 30 feet right of Sapphire Crack.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: 15 feet right of Raised by Wolves

content.description: This climb has a lot of variety for a Sugarite Climb. Chimneys, dihedrals, arets, slabs, overhangs, flares and fingers can all be found on it. It is similar in difficulty to S&M, and I think similar in quality as well. You be the judge.       Start in the chimney. Climb the chimney liberally using cracks on ether side until you get to the interesting cracks starting half way up the slab. Follow the cracks right up the middle of the slab which brings you directly under the main crack. The crux is the first half of this crack because it is slightly overhanging and flaring, than eases a bit for the second half.
content.protection: Bring some large gear and long slings to make the top anchor which is pretty easy to make.   This climb uses a lot of .5-2" cams and hexes.
content.location: We approached this climb from the top(cairn at top of climb) but it can be approached from the bottom if you want. 150' down the wall from the S&M Crack. There is an obvious chimney with a red slab and interesting spiderweb cracks on it at the bottom.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: 5 feet right of Spoticus.

content.description: Really fun route! Thin cruxy start up to another technical, sporty crux. Roof looks more intimidating than it is - really fun crack climbing up top with excellent edges for feet.
content.location: About 20 right of the dihedral section with The Pocket Rocket there is a splitter with a small roof about a third of the way up.

content.description: Climb to the top of the arrowhead-shaped flake, then up a small hands crack that gets smaller to fingers near 2/3 way up.
content.protection:
Hands sized cams with doubles in small cams. 

  Lack of anchor is overcome by an odd set up of large cams over the lip.
content.location: In the dihedral just left of a small overhang.

content.description: [Needs description. If you've climbed this route, please contact a MountainProject administrator to have the route assigned to you to write a personal description. Thank you.]
content.location: Up the nasty downward fairing dihedral, that has a fixed wire at it's apex.

content.description: Bush Doctor doesn’t seem to get as much attention as other climbs at Sugarite. It is a lot of fun!  There are fairly new looking chains at the top. Bush Doctor is the left side of the roof. Precarious moves get you around the roof to the left and then great jamming from there on up. I also enjoy climbing the right side of the roof, as well and continue up the right crack. I would call this Bush Doctor Right. Similar grading as the left. Lots of fun!
content.location: 30 feet left of Endless Summer

content.description: Basalt
